July 9 at 8:12 PM ·

It is with great sadness that we share the news of the passing of Scotty Shevlin. Scotty was “the voice” of Dobbs Ferry High School football for the past 39 years, and called the play-by-play at Gould for countless championships and state titles.

Part of what makes Dobbs Ferry such a special place is our proud history, and Scotty Shevlin will forever be part of the fabric of our village. While this is a sad day in Dobbs Ferry, we also join together to celebrate a life well lived. Rest In Peace, Scotty.

Announcement from Superintendent Dr. Lisa Brady --

On June 16th, the 2020-2021 Dobbs Ferry School Budget passed by a vote of 1,404 to 476. The budget will enable the District to continue to provide an outstanding education for all of our students within a sound financial framework, and we are grateful for your continued support, especially in these difficult times.

Residents elected incumbent Tracy Baron, who received 1,477 votes, and newcomer Massimo Bufalini, who received 927 votes, to the Board of Education. Thank you to Hudson Trader, who received 922 votes, for his interest in serving on the school board. Congratulations to Tracy and Massimo who will begin a new three-year term beginning July 1, 2020 and expiring on June 30, 2023.

Most importantly, thank you to our wonderful school community. The school budget results affirm our residents’ strong commitment to the Dobbs Ferry School District and its mission and vision. We are eagerly looking forward to September and an opportunity to get back in the classroom if possible.

With the nice weather upon us, and in keeping with our neighboring villages, we are happy to announce the re-opening of the Dobbs Ferry School District turf fields and tennis courts tomorrow, Thursday, May 21st.

The playgrounds at Springhurst Elementary School remain closed.

Per Governor Cuomo’s PAUSE executive order, this includes the following expectations:

- Users will maintain social distancing of at least six feet from each other
- Activities are non-contact
- Non-essential gatherings will not take place (this includes organized sports)
- The ongoing status of these facilities is dependent upon responsible use

Tennis Court Rules:

- To prevent long lines, please limit your playing time to one hour
- Singles only games are permitted
- Please wear a mask or face covering while waiting to use the courts
- No private lessons allowed

Wishing our community a Happy Memorial Day weekend ahead!

Dobbs Ferry Science Research
March 29 at 6:31 PM ·

Congratulations to Gayathri Nair! She won first place in her poster competition at Upstate Junior Science and Humanities Symposium! This state level competition has been held annually in Albany but they figured out a virtual solution 😊 YAY!

Nair's research focused on developing a deeper understanding of Toxoplasmosis. Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic infection. The parasite, Toxoplasma gondii, has been historically difficult to eradicate during infections due to its ability to defend itself against antibiotics. Nair was able to identify a possible genetic approach to disarming the parasite, thus making the illness more easily treatable.

This is the kind of research our world truly needs, these days! Great job, Gaya3!! ❤️❤️

While the Regeneron International Science and Engineering Fair (ISEF) 2020, scheduled for May 10-15 in Anaheim, California. has been officially cancelled, we are grateful to the Tarrytown based biotech company for not only supporting science research students, but also being at the forefront of trying to combat the Coronavirus (COVID-19).

During the 2018 outbreak of Ebola in the Congo, Regeneron quickly developed a promising monoclonal antibody triplet therapy that’s now under review by the U.S. FDA. Now, amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, the biotech is making headway.

Regeneron scientists have isolated hundreds of neutralizing antibodies against the SARS-CoV-2 virus from a humanized mouse model as well as from humans who have recovered from COVID-19, the company said Tuesday. Regeneron aims to enter clinical studies by early summer.

High Touch High Tech is a fun and interactive push-in, hands-on science experience. The program uses discovery style learning and inquiry-based dialogue that dovetails with the students’ curriculum. Thanks to a grant from the Dobbs Ferry Schools Foundation, Springhurst 1st graders engaged in experiments investigating light and sound waves, enriching the Science 21 unit they were studying in class.

During the 1 ½ hour session, the students participated in approximately eight experiments that all have real-world applications. Students used a tuning fork and cup to simulate an artificial eardrum and a slinky to demonstrate how sound waves move. Working with a foot-long ruler, the program’s visiting scientist showed students how to produce noise using different types of vibrations, build a black light tunnel from a paper towel tube and construct rubber band harmonicas. Students loved this STEM enrichment program and in-school “field trip.”
